Consumer Behavior

Cardinal Utility Approach

The cardinal utility approach assumes that utility can be measured numerically in "utils." According to the Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility, as a consumer consumes more units of a good, the additional satisfaction (marginal utility) derived from each successive unit decreases.

Figure 1: Diminishing Marginal Utility Curve

Ordinal Utility Theory

The ordinal approach suggests that consumers can rank their preferences but cannot measure utility precisely. Indifference curves represent all combinations of two goods that provide equal satisfaction to the consumer.

Figure 2: Indifference Curves showing different utility levels

Budget Constraints

The budget line shows all possible combinations of two goods a consumer can purchase given their income and the prices of the goods. The equation is:

P1X1 + P2X2 = M

Where P1 and P2 are prices, X1 and X2 are quantities, and M is income.

Consumer Equilibrium

Consumer equilibrium occurs where the budget line is tangent to the highest possible indifference curve. At this point:

MRS = P1/P2

Where MRS is the marginal rate of substitution (the slope of the indifference curve).

Market Structures

Perfect Competition

Characteristics:

  • Many buyers and sellers
  • Homogeneous products
  • Free entry and exit
  • Perfect information
  • Price takers (MR = MC = P)

Figure 1: characterstics of Perfect Competition

Monopoly

Characteristics:

  • Single seller
  • No close substitutes
  • Barriers to entry
  • Price maker
  • Produces where MR = MC but charges higher price

Figure 2: Monopoly Price and Output Determination

Oligopoly

Characteristics:

  • Few dominant firms
  • Interdependent decisions
  • May collude (cartels) or compete
  • Game theory applies
  • Kinked demand curve model

Monopolistic Competition

Characteristics:

  • Many firms with differentiated products
  • Some pricing power in short run
  • Zero economic profit in long run
  • Examples: restaurants, clothing brands
  • Excess capacity in long run

National Income

Gross Domestic Product (GDP)

GDP measures the total monetary value of all final goods and services produced within a country's borders over a specific period. It can be calculated using three approaches:

  • Production Approach: Sum of value added by all industries.
  • Income Approach: Sum of incomes earned (wages, profits, rents).
  • Expenditure Approach: C + I + G + (X - M), where C is consumption, I is investment, G is government spending, X is exports, and M is imports.

Gross National Product (GNP)

GNP measures the total monetary value of all final goods and services produced by a country's residents, regardless of location. GNP = GDP + Net income from abroad.

Measuring National Income

Other measures include Net National Product (NNP), which adjusts GNP for depreciation, and National Income (NI), which adjusts NNP for indirect taxes and subsidies.

Consumption & Investment

Consumption Function

The consumption function shows the relationship between consumption spending and disposable income: C = a + bY, where C is consumption, a is autonomous consumption, b is the marginal propensity to consume (MPC), and Y is disposable income.

Savings Patterns

Savings is the portion of disposable income not spent on consumption. The savings function is: S = -a + (1-b)Y, where 1-b is the marginal propensity to save (MPS).

Investment Determinants

Investment is influenced by:

  • Interest rates
  • Business expectations
  • Technological changes
  • Government policies

International Trade

Comparative Advantage

A country has a comparative advantage in producing a good if it can produce it at a lower opportunity cost than another country.

Balance of Payments

The balance of payments records all economic transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world, including the current account and capital account.

Exchange Rates

Exchange rates determine the value of one currency in terms of another. Systems include fixed, floating, and managed float regimes.

Economic Development

Human Development Index (HDI)

HDI measures a country’s development based on life expectancy, education, and per capita income.

Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)

The SDGs are 17 global goals set by the UN to address poverty, inequality, climate change, and other issues by 2030.

Growth vs Development

Economic growth refers to an increase in GDP, while development includes improvements in living standards, education, and health.
